son-montuno-suave.title: Son Montuno - Verse (Suave)
son-montuno-suave.description: The 'Verse' section of a salsa song is where the story begins. The percussionists use wood sounds (cascara on timbales, martillo on bongos) to create a smooth, flowing groove that supports the vocals.

musical_context.dance_feel: This is the storytelling section. Dancers should feel the smooth, flowing rhythm. The clave is subtle but always present.

instruments.name: Timbales (Cascara)
instruments.pattern_description: Playing on the side of the drum (cascara) creates a wood-like texture. The pattern emphasizes the off-beats.
instruments.tip: The cascara pattern helps you feel the syncopation. Listen for the 'and' of beats 2 and 4.

instruments.name: Bongo (Martillo)
instruments.pattern_description: The 'hammer' pattern alternates between high and low bongo drums, creating a constant rhythmic pulse.
instruments.tip: The bongo martillo is like a metronome - it keeps the tempo steady. Use it to find your '1'.

instruments.name: Conga (Tumbao)
instruments.pattern_description: Standard 1-drum tumbao pattern. The 'Slap' is on beat 2, and the 'Open Tones' are on beat 4 and 4-and.
instruments.tip: Listen to the 'Slap' to find your timing for Copas and checks. The conga is the foundation.

instruments.name: Piano (Comping)
instruments.pattern_description: Simple chord comping that supports the melody. Less syncopated than the montuno section.
instruments.tip: The piano in the verse is more supportive. Save your energy for when the montuno kicks in!

son-montuno-fuerte.title: Son Montuno - Montuno Section (High Energy)
son-montuno-fuerte.description: The 'Montuno' is the call-and-response section of a salsa song where the energy peaks. The percussionists switch from wood (cascara) to metal (bells) to drive the dancers.

musical_context.dance_feel: This is when you do your turns and shines. The heavy cowbell marks the beat 1, 3, 5, 7. Energy is high!

instruments.name: Congas (2-Drum Tumbao)
instruments.pattern_description: More complex tumbao with two drums. The 'Slap' is on beat 2, and the 'Open Tones' are on beat 4 and 4-and.
instruments.tip: Listen to the 'Slap' to find your timing for Copas and checks. The energy is higher here.

instruments.name: Bongo Bell (Campana)
instruments.pattern_description: Played by the Bongocero during the chorus. It emphasizes the downbeats (1, 3, 5, 7).
instruments.tip: If you get lost, find the loud cowbell. It is usually marking the main pulse. This is your anchor!

instruments.name: Timbales (Mambo Bell)
instruments.pattern_description: Switches from cascara to the mambo bell (cowbell) on the timbales. Creates the driving energy.
instruments.tip: The mambo bell is what makes dancers want to turn and shine. Feel that energy!

instruments.name: Piano (Montuno)
instruments.pattern_description: A syncopated arpeggio that outlines the chords. It creates tension by rarely playing on beat 1.
instruments.tip: Dancers often mistake the Piano's 'and of 1' for the actual '1'. Be careful! The piano anticipates the beat.

cha-cha-cha.title: Cha Cha Chá
cha-cha-cha.description: Cha Cha Chá is a Cuban dance rhythm that's slower than salsa but has a distinctive 'cha-cha-cha' pattern. It's perfect for beginners to learn timing.

musical_context.dance_feel: Slower and more relaxed than salsa. The 'cha-cha-cha' happens on beats 4-and-1. Perfect for learning the basics.

instruments.name: Güiro (Down-Up Stroke)
instruments.pattern_description: The güiro creates the distinctive 'cha-cha-cha' sound with down-up scraping strokes.
instruments.tip: The güiro pattern is what makes cha-cha-chá recognizable. Listen for the scraping sound on beats 4-and-1.

instruments.name: Conga (Tumbao - No Slap)
instruments.pattern_description: Simpler tumbao pattern without the heavy slap. More open tones for a lighter feel.
instruments.tip: The conga in cha-cha is lighter than salsa. Focus on the open tones.

instruments.name: Timbales (Cha Cha Bell)
instruments.pattern_description: Small bell pattern that marks the main beats. Less aggressive than mambo bell.
instruments.tip: The cha-cha bell is softer than the mambo bell. It marks the tempo without overwhelming.

mambo-classic.title: Mambo (Classic Big Band)
mambo-classic.description: Mambo is the fast-paced, high-energy section where horns take over. This is the 'shines' section where dancers show off their footwork.

musical_context.dance_feel: High energy! This is where you do your shines and fancy footwork. The tempo is fast and the horns drive the energy.

instruments.name: Sax/Brass (Moñas)
instruments.pattern_description: Horn riffs (moñas) that create the melodic hooks. These are the 'hooks' that dancers respond to.
instruments.tip: The horns tell you when to turn and shine. Listen for the melodic phrases.

instruments.name: Timbales (Songo or Mambo Bell)
instruments.pattern_description: Aggressive bell pattern that drives the energy. Can be songo pattern or straight mambo bell.
instruments.tip: The timbales in mambo are LOUD. They drive the energy and mark every beat.

instruments.name: Bass (Syncopated Tumbao)
instruments.pattern_description: Syncopated bass line that anticipates the beat. Creates the 'lift' that makes dancers want to move.
instruments.tip: The bass in mambo is very syncopated. It 'anticipates' the beat, creating forward momentum.

bolero.title: Bolero / Bachata
bolero.description: Bolero is the romantic, slow section of salsa songs. It's also the foundation of bachata. Perfect for learning timing at a slower pace.

musical_context.dance_feel: Slow and romantic. This is the 'close embrace' section. Perfect for beginners to learn the basic step.

instruments.name: Conga (Bolero Pattern)
instruments.pattern_description: Simplified conga pattern with emphasis on beats 1 and 3. Much slower than salsa tumbao.
instruments.tip: The bolero conga is slow and steady. Use it to practice your basic step timing.

instruments.name: Maracas (Constant Shaker)
instruments.pattern_description: Constant shaker pattern that provides texture. Steady and consistent.
instruments.tip: The maracas provide a steady pulse. They're like a metronome for the slow tempo.

instruments.name: Bongo (Variations)
instruments.pattern_description: Varied bongo patterns that add interest without overwhelming the slow tempo.
instruments.tip: The bongo in bolero is subtle. It adds color without dominating.

afro-6-8.title: 6/8 (Afro-Cuban Rumba)
afro-6-8.description: 6/8 time is the foundation of Afro-Cuban rumba and many folkloric rhythms. It's polyrhythmic and complex, but essential for understanding salsa's roots.

musical_context.dance_feel: Complex and polyrhythmic. This is the 'roots' of salsa. Feel the 6/8 pulse - it's different from 4/4!

instruments.name: Clave (6/8 Clave)
instruments.pattern_description: 6/8 clave pattern that creates the polyrhythmic foundation. Different from 2-3 or 3-2 son clave.
instruments.tip: The 6/8 clave feels different from 4/4. Count it as '1-2-3, 4-5-6' instead of '1-2-3-4'.

instruments.name: Conga (Open Tones - Polyrhythm)
instruments.pattern_description: Polyrhythmic conga pattern with open tones that create cross-rhythms against the 6/8 clave.
instruments.tip: The conga in 6/8 creates polyrhythms. Don't try to count it - just feel it!
